text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
The IPM IRM Policy has been updated to include the required Internal Controls.
IRM 2.100.1 dated January 30, 2017, is superseded.
This Policy is applicable to all information Technology (IT) organizations, contractors, and other responsibility for developing IT processes.

Scope
Authority

Management Policy
) Overview - This document describes the formal policy for implementing the requirements of the Integrated Process Management (IPM) process. (

) Purpose - This Directive serves as the policy for the Integrated Process agement (IPM) program. This program will support the Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI), Information Technology Infrastructure Library Project Management Institute (PMI), and other process framework, model, life cycle effort for the IT organization. (
) Audience - This Policy is applicable to all information Technology (IT) tions, contractors, and other stakeholders having responsibility for IT processes. (
) Policy Owner - The Enterprise Operations (EOPs) Associate Chief Officer (ACIO) is the policy owner. (
) Program Owner - The Demand Management and Project Governance Director is the program owner. (
) Primary Stakeholders - This Directive applies to all IT process owners lishing new or revised processes. (

) Program Goals - The process goal describes a speciﬁc purpose or achieve- ment toward which the efforts of the process are directed. Each process speciﬁc focus and when combined with the other processes, forms a hensive framework for delivering and managing services. The goal of IPM is enable a consistent and integrated approach to process implementation and execution across the IT organization. (

) The Demand Management and Project Governance (DMPG) in Enterprise erations is responsible for the development, implementation, and of this directive. Approval of this directive, including updates, rests with the formation Technology (IT) Chief Information Officer (CIO) and Associate Information Officer (ACIO) for Enterprise Operations. All proposed changes this directive must be submitted to DMPG. (
) This Directive applies to all IT process owners establishing new or revised processes. (
) The CIO mandated the implementation of Information Technology Library (ITIL), Capability Maturity Model Integration (CMMI), and Project agement Institute (PMI) standards. (

) In accordance with the CIO mandate for the implementation of ITIL, CMMI PMI standards, the IPM process will ensure that IT is meeting its goals and delivering beneﬁts that facilitate change, transformation, and growth of IT processes and services. IPM will standardize and centralize processes in mation Technology Process Asset Library (IT PAL) and will facilitate IT core enterprise processes through the Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) for imple- menting a standard in process documentation and institutionalization. (
) The IPM process will enable: Internal Revenue Manual
Process Management Policy 2.100.1
Audience - This Policy is applicable to all information Technology (IT) organiza- tions, contractors, and other stakeholders having responsibility for developing

) In accordance with the CIO mandate for the implementation of ITIL, CMMI and PMI standards, the IPM process will ensure that IT is meeting its goals and delivering beneﬁts that facilitate change, transformation, and growth of IT processes and services. IPM will standardize and centralize processes in Infor- mation Technology Process Asset Library (IT PAL) and will facilitate IT core or enterprise processes through the Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) for imple- menting a standard in process documentation and institutionalization.
2.100 Integrated Process Management
The deﬁnitive identiﬁcation of all of IT core or enterprise processes provide the resources from within and across the organization to support the IRS mission. An enterprise

level establishment of standards and best practices for the essential elements of effective processes, moving from ad hoc, immature processes to documenting and centralizing disciplined and mature processes improved with quality and effectiveness. The development of the Integrated Process Architecture (IPA), display

ing the ordering, interfaces, interdependencies, and other relationships among the fundamental units (elements) of our core process. It will provide the rules for connecting the process elements of a process, cover the essential requirements and guidelines, and specify the relationships between the elements in diagram form. IPM to serve as the foundation for driving change management, providing stakeholders the ability to analyze process interfaces for tiﬁcation of overlaps, redundancies, and impacts to other process via IPA. IPA to provide a medium to expose process improvement opportunities at a glance.
